captions.text:
SHANE SMITH: After getting
kicked out of the logging

camp, we headed into
the forest in

The Fish knew all the lumber
hot spots, and, after some

very lurchy driving, he
found us a working

This guy is really going
to want to talk to us.

Maybe I should soften it up a
bit with the shotgun before we

get out, so they know
we mean business.

SHANE SMITH: After our heated
words at the logging camp, we

decided to try to irrigate
the conversation with the

SHANE SMITH: Hey,
you want a beer?

SHANE SMITH: Dude's got
an iron bar there.

How long have they been
working here?

SHANE SMITH: And do they
live out here?

SHANE SMITH: And how long do
they have to stay here before

SHANE SMITH: So what he's
saying here is that the

majority of workers have a
10-year-plus labor commitment

to live and work out in
the middle of nowhere

And when we asked him about days
off, he seemed confused.

SHANE SMITH: And are they
happy to be here?
SHANE SMITH: Here comes a van.

We were talking to our
North Korean friends.

SHANE SMITH: --and they're
now coming to get us.

SHANE SMITH: Who
are these guys?

SIMON OSTROVSKY: It's the
guy in the blue jacket

Oh, he's the secretary of the
party organization here.

So the secretary of the party
organization has come.

They're going be told
not to talk to us.

SHANE SMITH: We promised
to go away from there.

SIMON OSTROVSKY: He's saying
he's going to tell the Tynda

captain boss that this
guy's helping us out.

SHANE SMITH: It was right
around here that

Yeah, these guys are
coming back here.

The dude with the crowbar
is coming back.

SHANE SMITH: We're in a
high-speed car chase at five

miles an hour through the
wilds of Siberia.

It's a game of chicken out
in the middle of nowhere.

title: North Korean Labor Camps - VICE NEWS - Part 6 of 7

extra money.

comments.text:
+bethbearmacethatguy y

Korea doesn't interact with the outside world any longer. Not to mention 
these people aren't even from North Korea. They're speaking the wrong 
dialect and they aren't the correct colour. Either of these two things 
being incorrect would debunk racism and dialectics in North Korea. Figure 
out what lies you want to put forth first.

On a different note, North Korea really doesn't interact with Russia. The 
only time they ever had directly interacted was during the Korean War. 
China *was* the main supplier of North Korea before that. These people 
clearly are either South Korean or from a more southern region of Asia. 

*Even if* this labour camp shit in Siberia was legit, Russia would be to 
blame for the conditions. Russia being capitalist.

comments.author: ray101mond

comments.text:
+Yudhistir s

Are you really comparing an embassy, somewhere politicians meet, to a work 
camp? There's also the fact that North Korea doesn't interact with Russia 
anymore. Considering Russia is completely capitalist now.

+Jz80 

All countries have prisons that offer working for reduced sentences. North 
Korea is no different in this regard. The only difference between north 
koreas camps and America's camps is that North Korea has camps and prisons. 
Rather than all prisons being equipped with the ability to basically be 
slavery.

And again, I don't see how it would be economical to force most of your 
population into slavery. There's literally nothing backing this other than 
a few bullshit documentaries. Most of which are staged, misrepresented, 
mistranslated, misinterpreted or downright lies. I've actually seen some 
Southeast asian people labelled as North Koreans. 

Which again, I've said this before. If North Korea is supposedly racist, 
why would they have brown people working for them? Wouldn't they want to 
get rid of them? Don't they kill people of other races? Get your stories 
straight before making up bullshit.

comments.text:
I feel like Vice is not being sensitive to how harshly the North Koreans 
they have talked to may or may not be punished.  The workers that they gave 
beers to ended up being carted off by the leader of the camp to who knows 
where, and will probably get in big trouble for having talked to them. 
 It's very obvious how invasive and rude the reporters are being by 
basically saying "hey we heard this is a shity place and we want to come 
videotape your shity lives."  Number one, that's just offensive to the 
people, and beyond that, the Koreans are forced to by their country to 
defend what is happening, or otherwise face trial as someone who is 
betraying their country.  I understand Vice wants to expose this sort of 
thing, and that it needs to be done, but I believe that it should be done 
in a more careful manner.﻿

comments.author: EpicMoose12345

comments.text:
There is something so great, extreme and humane about these types of 
documentaries/news clips. Not just Russian Lumber Camps. But all of these 
things that are forgotten or not on the radar: Cannibal warlords in 
Liberia, Moonshine brewing in Africa, Guerilla Gardeners in Atlanta, 
Vigilante Mobs in Johannesburg etc. etc. etc.

Colorful, and fascinating. Even the drunken Russian on the train was 
interesting!﻿
